As soon as it would cut out it would start back up again. It sometimes would happen a few times in a row . Or it would happen just once. There is no real Ryme or reason it does it. You could just be driving foward and then it stops and start or you could be turning while moving and it happens. No CAN bus errors were displayed. It is like the delay of the robot code could be causing problems with the refresh rates of the motor controllers. Also, for context there is both else running in the code except for the drive Sirota","username":"gdgr","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/f1d935/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-12-12T20:07:25.100Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe also have been seeing this with our YAGSL bot. It definitely happens with a low battery, but even with a fresh battery, on the driver station it appears to be network dropouts. We found that one of our driver station computers seems to do it less than the other one, though it’s not really scientific.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLast year, my team (a different team) had a similar problem with network issues. Turned out to be a process running on the RoboRIO (FRC_NetcommDaemon) was running away with the CPU for reasons no one knows. Killing the process it fixed it. Never happened during comps, only during testing, never fully resolved. Our theory was that something we were doing in our robot code was overtaxing the network and this particular FRC thing couldn’t handle it, but we never figured out what it was. This year, we haven’t had a chance to check if it’s the same thing or not.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-12-12T20:07:25.100Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":446044,"topic_slug":"yagsl-swerve-stopping-and-starting-randomly","display_username":"Josh href=\"https://github.com/7657thunderbots/7657SwerveYAGSLCode/blob/master/src%2Fmain%2Fjava%2Ffrc%2Frobot%2Fsubsystems%2Fswervedrive%2FSwerveSubsystem.java#L53\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003e7657thunderbots/7657SwerveYAGSLCode/blob/master/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/swervedrive/SwerveSubsystem.java#L53\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\n\n\n    \u003cpre class=\"onebox\"\u003e\u003ccode class=\"lang-java\"\u003e\n      \u003col class=\"start lines\" start=\"43\" style=\"counter-reset: li-counter 42 ;\"\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003eprivate       SwerveAutoBuilder autoBuilder = null;\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e/**\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e * Initialize {@link SwerveDrive} with the directory provided.\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e *\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e * @param directory Directory of swerve drive config files.\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e */\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003epublic SwerveSubsystem(File directory)\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e{\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  // Configure the Telemetry before creating the SwerveDrive to avoid unnecessary objects being created.\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli class=\"selected\"\u003e  SwerveDriveTelemetry.verbosity = TelemetryVerbosity.HIGH;\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  try\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  {\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e    swerveDrive = new SwerveParser(directory).createSwerveDrive();\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  } catch (Exception e)\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  {\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e    throw new RuntimeException(e);\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e  }\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e}\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n          \u003cli\u003e/**\u003c/li\u003e\n      \u003c/ol\u003e\n    \u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\n\n\n  \u003c/article\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv class=\"onebox-metadata\"\u003e\n    \n    \n  \u003c/div\u003e\n\n  \u003cdiv style=\"clear: both\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/aside\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eto\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ccode\u003eTelemetryVerbosity.NONE\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe network packet loss is very high and is probably forcing watchdogs to stop motors since communication could not be heard from fast enough causing these issues. This means that reducing network congestions like camera streams, and rapid network table updates, could remedy this. It could be the issue \u003ca class=\"mention\" href=\"/u/gdgr\"\u003e@gdgr\u003c/a\u003e but you would need to ssh into the roboRIO and look at CPU usage while the program is running or capture that data. If you hide network packets on the log viewer and see CPU spikes at the same places just as high or almost as high then \u003ca class=\"mention\" href=\"/u/gdgr\"\u003e@gdgr\u003c/a\u003e 's problem becomes more
